subject: Re: Finally a reply
msgSnippet: I keep a journal - a few entries a week - in QS, just to keep my hand in.I also use it in interviews or when I m assessing people in work,
messageBody:
I keep a journal - a few entries a week - in QS, just to keep my hand in. I also use it in interviews or when I'm assessing people in work, face="jerome">abrapt or face="jerome">snoti don't look so bad in Read. I've never worried too much about dictionary spellings, and I quite enjoy hearing my own voice in the writing - obviously I'd try and modify this if I was writing for an audience, but that aint likely yet. The Read Alphabet introductory book has a lot of useful words and, spread thoughout it, are good examples of a 'standard' way to spell common sound combinations which might be the basis of a dictionary (has anyone compiled these alphabetically?). Personally, I can live without the agonising over gradations of sound in regional accents which the Shavian list seem to enjoy. I enjoy writing by hand rather than typing because I haven't had time to really get stuck into itthe typing convention. (I still haven't worked out where all the half letters are in Jerome and have to keep 'character map' open.) cheers, face="jerome">.mFk

Content-Type: text/html; charset=iso-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit

I keep a journal - a few entries a week - in QS, just to keep my hand in.
I also use it in interviews or when I'm assessing people in work, <font> face="jerome">abrapt</font> or <font> face="jerome">snoti</font> don't look so bad in Read.

I've never worried too much about dictionary spellings, and I quite enjoy hearing my own voice in the writing - obviously I'd try and modify this if I was writing for an audience, but that aint likely yet.

The Read Alphabet introductory book has a lot of useful words and, spread thoughout it, are good examples of a 'standard' way to spell common sound combinations which might be the basis of a dictionary (has anyone compiled these alphabetically?). Personally, I can live without the agonising over gradations of sound in regional accents which the Shavian list seem to enjoy.

I enjoy writing by hand rather than typing because I haven't had time to really get stuck into itthe typing convention. (I still haven't worked out where all the half letters are in Jerome and have to keep 'character map' open.)

 cheers,
<font> face="jerome">.mFk</font> 

 <p><p><br><hr size=1><a href="http://uk.yahoo.com/mail/tagline_xtra/?http://uk.docs.yahoo.com/mail_storage.html"><b><font face="Arial" size="2">Get a bigger mailbox -- choose a size that fits your needs.</font></b></a><br><br><a href="http://uk.yahoo.com/mail/tagline_xtra/?http://uk.docs.yahoo.com/mail_storage.html"><font face="Arial" size="2">http://uk.docs.yahoo.com/mail_storage.html</font></a>
